Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of establishment in Canada and hardship in the Philippines
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; officer's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual or disproportionate hardship
Credibility_Factor: Officer found insufficient evidence of hardship despite HIV status and discrimination claims
Legal_Rule: H&C exemptions available under IRPA for unusual or disproportionate hardship
Grounds_for_Claim: Medical inadmissibility due to HIV, risk of disrupted treatment and discrimination in home country
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; officer's assessment found reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Establishment in Canada, access to HIV treatment, potential discrimination in the Philippines
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds provisions under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer denied application citing insufficient hardship evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of residence, health records, country condition reports
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence in Canada on H&C grounds
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA allowing H&C considerations

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Family sought to remain in Canada due to daughter Rhea's pediatric cancer treatment
Evidence of medical needs and challenges accessing adequate care in India was presented
Claimant_Status: Applicants for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with immigration status prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider best interests of the child (BIOC)
Misinterpretation of data on Indian pediatric oncology services
Dismissal of crucial medical and family establishment evidence
Evidence_Used: Documentation of treatment received in Canada
Evidence of family ties and integration in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to adequately assess submitted medical evidence
Lack of meaningful engagement with BIOC considerations
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application by immigration officer
Relief_Sought: Remain in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable due to failure to properly analyze key factors including BIOC and quality of medical care abroad
Insufficient justification for dismissing evidence on India's pediatric oncology capacity

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of extrinsic evidence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation via reliance on sister's removal order

Application_Facts: Applied for permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Use of extrinsic evidence without explicit notice
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's decision
Breach of procedural fairness due to lack of oral interview
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of disproportionate hardship
Unverified psychologist's opinion on conditions in Korea
Inference of family support based on past support
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Psychologist's report deemed unverified
Officer's reasonable inference about family support
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness does not always require an oral hearing
Standard of review is reasonableness for H&C decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonable decision
Alleged breach of procedural fairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision found reasonable
Defendant_Response: Officer reasonably assessed hardship and family support
No requirement for oral interview
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of refusal of H&C application

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence linking general conditions in Haiti to personal situation
Legal_Provision: s. 25, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision
Evidence_Assessment: Officer properly assessed evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant
Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence
Legal_Rule: s. 25 IRPA â€“ humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper assessment of evidence
Failure to consider moratoriums
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa multiple times, established ties in Canada, claimed hardship due to family connections
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application for permanent residency
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of unusual hardship; illegal employment; limited dependency on Canadian family

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and compassionate application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision to deny H&C application

Legal_Issue: Whether H&R Block infringed U&R Tax Services' copyright by copying their 1988 T1 General Draft Form
Evidence_Assessment: U&R's original creation of the draft form using skill and judgment, predating government release; H&R's access to and photocopying of the form with minor changes
Decision_Outcome: In favor of U&R Tax Services
Burden_of_Proof: On U&R to prove originality, ownership, and substantial copying
Credibility_Factor: Evidence that H&R accessed and used U&R's form prior to making modifications
Legal_Rule: Copyright subsists in every original literary work; infringement occurs when a substantial part is reproduced without consent
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized reproduction of a substantial part of a copyrighted work
Outcome_on_Merits: H&R found liable for copyright infringement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Originality of U&R's form, access by H&R, similarity between forms, impact on U&R's business
Defendant_Response: H&R denied liability and filed a counterclaim
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (draft tax forms), business records, testimony on use and distribution
Outcome: Court awarded U&R $145,010 in damages; H&R's counterclaim dismissed
Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing complaints under s. 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to warrant further inquiry
Decision_Outcome: Complaint dismissed by the Commission; decision upheld by Federal Court
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate reasonable grounds for inquiry
Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly challenged; insufficient evidence rather than credibility issues
Legal_Rule: The Commission may dismiss a complaint if an inquiry is not warranted based on the evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination by Canada Post and its employees
Outcome_on_Merits: No finding of discrimination due to lack of sufficient evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Investigation findings, lack of corroborative evidence
Defendant_Response: Canada Post and employees denied discriminatory conduct
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, witness statements (if any), investigation report
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether it was reasonable for the Minister's delegate to deny Mr. Fleet's request for relief from penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Fleet provided insufficient evidence to support his claim that CRA delays contributed to his failure to file; reliance on advisors was noted but not excused
Decision_Outcome: Denial of relief from penalties and interest was upheld as reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the taxpayer to demonstrate extenuating circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Fleet's claims were partially undermined by lack of supporting evidence
Legal_Rule: Section 220(3.1) allows waiver of penalties/interest if extenuating circumstances exist; taxpayers are accountable for actions of their advisors
Grounds_for_Claim: RRSP over-contribution due to erroneous advice from employer; request for penalty and interest relief
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Reliance on financial advisors, missed filing deadlines, failure to submit T1-OVP returns, alleged CRA processing delays
Defendant_Response: Mr. Fleet blamed CRA delays and relied on professional advice, but did not provide sufficient documentation
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, taxpayer testimony, administrative records
Remedy_Requested: Waiver or cancellation of penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Outcome: Application dismissed; no costs awarded due to government error in advising Mr. Fleet
Authority: Minister's delegate, Tax Court of Canada

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer's analysis of child's best interests under IRPA s. 25(1)
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to properly weigh Leticia's Canadian citizenship and lack of connection to Brazil
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Rule: IRPA s. 25(1) requires consideration of H&C grounds including best interests of the child without applying hardship thresholds
Grounds_for_Claim: Best interests of the child, Canadian citizenship, lack of ties to country of origin
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Child's Canadian citizenship, lack of connection to Brazil, family support in Brazil
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds provisions under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Officer applied incorrect 'basic amenities' test
Outcome: Application allowed; remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)

Dispute_Type: Housing allocation and transfer of tenancy rights
Legal_Issue: Whether Robin Roberts has a right to remain in the housing unit and is entitled to an injunction against eviction
Evidence_Assessment: Robin failed to provide concrete evidence of efforts to find alternative accommodation; no clear proof of irreparable harm
Burden_of_Proof: On Robin Roberts to demonstrate serious issue, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Lack of documented efforts to secure alternate housing
Legal_Rule: (1) Serious issue to be tried, (2) Irreparable harm if injunction not granted, (3) Balance of convenience favors injunction
Grounds_for_Claim: Right to remain based on tenancy dispute within First Nation reserve
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to insufficient evidence and lack of legal justification
Key_Evidence_Considered: Claim of having nowhere else to go, lack of documentation on housing search
Legal_Framework: Injunction law under Canadian common law (RJR-MacDonald test)
Evidence_Type: Oral claims, lack of documentary evidence
Outcome: Eviction ordered; seven days to vacate, temporary restoration of electricity, no costs awarded
Legal_Provision: Common law principles governing interim injunctions

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'CuvÃ©e ImpÃ©riale Berlucchi' was used in association with sparkling wines during the relevant period
Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of invoice and label evidence for sale of 300 bottles to Brunello Imports Inc.
Decision_Outcome: Trademark registration reinstated for sparkling wines
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner (Berlucchi) to demonstrate use under s. 4 of the Trademarks Act
Credibility_Factor: Ambiguities in evidence raised by Registrar; credibility of submitted documentation
Legal_Rule: A trademark is deemed used if marked on wares or associated such that notice is given to the transferee in normal trade (s. 45, Trademarks Act)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable in administrative appeals
Grounds_for_Claim: Registrar's decision to expunge due to alleged insufficient evidence of use
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal allowed; registration restored based on sufficient evidence of use
Key_Evidence_Considered: Invoice and product label showing the trademark on a sale of sparkling wine
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trademarks Act, including provisions on use and maintenance of registration
Defendant_Response: Registrar doubted use due to ambiguities in evidence
Outcome: Court allowed the appeal and restored the trademark registration

Legal_Issue: Whether the Athletic Club Trade-mark is invalid under sections 12(1)(b), 12(1)(c), and 10 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Cross-examinations, newspaper articles, Yellow Pages listings, corporate/trade-name searches
Decision_Outcome: The Athletic Club Trade-mark declared invalid
Burden_of_Proof: On Ottawa Athletic Club to prove invalidity
Credibility_Factor: Evidence of widespread industry use of 'athletic club' prior to 1997
Legal_Rule: A trade-mark is invalid if it is clearly descriptive, merely the name of services, or prohibited by ordinary commercial usage
Grounds_for_Claim: Descriptiveness, genericness, and prohibition under commercial usage
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld; trademark invalidated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of 'athletic club' in industry publications, directories, and business names before 1997
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but implied defense of trademark validity
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, public records, commercial usage data
Remedy_Requested: Invalidation and removal of the Athletic Club Trade-mark from the register
Outcome: Trademark invalidated and ordered removed; permanent prohibition on use

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of breach, including admission by Mr. Falcon
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Falcon admitted to entering the clothing store

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'BEST CANADIAN MOTOR INNS & Design' is clearly descriptive under section 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Opposition before the Trade-marks Opposition Board; appeal to the Federal Court under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Design elements were considered, but dominant words found to make the mark clearly descriptive; new expert evidence on distinctiveness of design did not alter the outcome
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate registrability of the trademark
Credibility_Factor: Expert evidence submitted but not sufficient to overcome descriptiveness finding
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b) prohibits registration of clearly descriptive trademarks
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable in administrative appeals under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on confusion and descriptiveness
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark refused registration for being clearly descriptive
Key_Evidence_Considered: Textual content of the mark, design elements, expert testimony on visual impression
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative opposition and appeal process
Defendant_Response: Opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness and potential confusion
Outcome: Registrar's decision upheld; appeal dismissed with costs to Respondent

Dispute_Type: Trademark infringement liability of corporate officer
Legal_Issue: Whether there is a genuine issue for trial regarding Mr. Kichuk's personal liability for trademark infringement
Governing_Law: Principles of personal liability for directors and officers in trademark infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Kichuk conducted a trademark search that did not reveal the 'ISO-FLEX' mark; he had no prior knowledge of the plaintiffs or their products; post-adoption events were considered but found insufficient to establish liability
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs failed to show genuine issue of material fact regarding personal liability
Credibility_Factor: Defendant's lack of knowledge and good faith adoption of the mark
Legal_Rule: Directors and officers are personally liable if their conduct is tortious or shows deliberate, willful indifference to the risk of infringement
Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard â€“ whether a genuine issue for trial exists
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged personal involvement in trademark infringement through corporate actions
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed on merits due to lack of evidence supporting personal liability
Key_Evidence_Considered: Trademark search results, defendantâ€™s knowledge (or lack thereof), timing of mark adoption, absence of willful infringement
Legal_Framework: U.S. trademark law principles on vicarious and direct liability for corporate officers
Defendant_Response: Lack of knowledge, good faith selection of mark, no deliberate or willful conduct
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (trademark search), sworn statements, procedural record
Remedy_Requested: Dismissal of claims against Mr. Kichuk and Mr. Glover
Outcome: Summary judgment granted, claims dismissed with costs
Legal_Provision: Federal trademark law (implied under Lanham Act principles)
Authority: Court decision on motion for summary judgment

Dispute_Type: Employment dispute involving termination and alleged discrimination
Legal_Issue: Whether the layoff was due to legitimate reorganization or constituted unjust dismissal
Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator found no evidence of bad faith or subterfuge; employer provided evidence of large-scale restructuring
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; adjudicator's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Employer must prove economic justification and reasonable, non-discriminatory criteria for layoffs
Credibility_Factor: No indication of dishonesty or improper motive in termination decision
Legal_Rule: Layoff due to lack of work or discontinuance of function is not unjust dismissal under Canada Labour Code s. 242(3.1)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unjust dismissal and discriminatory practices in termination
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; termination found to be part of legitimate reorganization
Key_Evidence_Considered: Large-scale restructuring, non-discriminatory layoff criteria, absence of bad faith
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code, administrative law principles on reasonableness
Defendant_Response: Termination was due to legitimate business reorganization and economic reasons
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of restructuring, layoff criteria, organizational changes

Legal_Issue: Whether the Director General breached the duty of fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to objections
Evidence_Assessment: Failure to provide opportunity to respond to objections prior to decision
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness may require providing parties an opportunity to address objections in administrative processes
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness, depending on context
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness in approval process
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim successful
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of objections and lack of response opportunity
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice
Defendant_Response: Director General proceeded with decision without addressing applicant's right to reply
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision via certiorari, costs
Outcome: Decision quashed, costs awarded to applicant, no referral back under s. 18

Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over entitlement to benefits
Legal_Issue: Whether the denial of the veteran's disability pension is justified under applicable laws and evidence
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Evidence_Assessment: Medical reports linking neck condition to 1983-1984 fall; lack of contemporaneous service documentation; contradictory discharge paperwork; medical opinions deemed speculative
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish causal linkage between injury and military service
Credibility_Factor: Uncontradicted evidence must be accepted unless found incredible; doubts resolved in favor of applicant
Legal_Rule: Causal linkage between injury and service must be established; uncontradicted evidence binding unless incredible
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in fact or law by the Board in denying pension application
Outcome_on_Merits: Pension denial maintained due to insufficient proof of causal linkage
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports, discharge documents, absence of contemporaneous injury records
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act; administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Board relied on discharge paperwork denying injury claims and found medical opinions speculative
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, medical opinion, administrative records
Legal_Provision: Provisions of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act regarding benefit eligibility and evidentiary standards

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in law by failing to consider the applicant's aptitude and future potential
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's skills, experience, initiative, efforts to upgrade qualifications, bonus units, total score of 45/55
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate legal error by the visa officer
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's limited initiative and lack of qualification upgrades considered
Legal_Rule: Visa officer must assess skills, experience, and aptitudes; discretion allowed under Section 11(3) if units don't reflect establishment chances
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to consider aptitude and future potential
Outcome_on_Merits: No legal error found in the visa officer's assessment
Key_Evidence_Considered: Job-related skills, experience, initiative, qualification upgrades, scoring under immigration system
Defendant_Response: Visa officer properly assessed all relevant factors including aptitude
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, scoring records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officer's decision

Legal_Issue: Did the Visa Officer err in refusing Mr. Sahota's application for permanent residence as a self-employed person?
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Sahota had over 30 years of farming experience but lacked knowledge of Canadian farming practices, specifics about his proposed farm, crops, geography, and business plan realism.
Decision_Outcome: The judicial review application was dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Mr. Sahota) to demonstrate eligibility as a self-employed person
Credibility_Factor: Limited understanding of Canadian farming and unrealistic business plan affected credibility
Legal_Rule: A 'self-employed person' must have relevant experience, intention, and ability to contribute economically to Canada.
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Visa Officer in assessing intentions and abilities of applicant
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa Officerâ€™s decision upheld as reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Farming experience, knowledge of Canadian agriculture, proposed business plan, understanding of geography and crops
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer found insufficient intention and ability based on lack of detailed planning and local knowledge
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application materials, officer's assessment
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn refusal of permanent residency application
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; refusal of residency upheld
Legal_Provision: Section related to self-employed persons under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over forfeiture timing
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether it is just and equitable to grant an extension of time to object to the Notice of Ascertained Forfeiture
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time after missed deadline
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minor two-day delay due to lawyer's computational error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show bona fide intention and that it is just and equitable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prompt action by Mr. Heron after realizing delay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension allowed under s. 129.2 if within one year, bona fide intent, and just and equitable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Miscalculation of 90-day deadline by legal counsel
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Objection deemed timely upon court order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of filing, reason for delay, lack of prejudice to Minister
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Sought extension from Minister and then Federal Court
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file objection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over forfeiture timing
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether it is just and equitable to grant an extension of time to object to the Notice of Ascertained Forfeiture
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time after missed deadline

Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show bona fide intention and that it is just and equitable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prompt action by Mr. Heron after realizing delay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension allowed under s. 129.2 if within one year, bona fide intent, and just and equitable

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Objection deemed timely upon court order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of filing, reason for delay, lack of prejudice to Minister

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Victim of financial fraud impacting immigration proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fraud and resulting hardship justify deferral of removal

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Allegations of victimization by fraud assessed but not determinative

Crimes.Defendant_Response: N/A â€“ Applicants were respondents seeking relief

Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal on humanitarian grounds

Legal_Issue: Whether failure to use the trademark 'Fascination' for three years constitutes special circumstances excusing non-use under s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant provided no evidence of when use would resume or specific obstacles preventing use; recession deemed a common situation, not special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to prove special circumstances justifying non-use
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence from appellant regarding future use or external obstacles
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45(3), a trademark may be expunged if not in use and absence of use is not due to special circumstances beyond the owner's control
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark for over three years without justification by special circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: Appellant failed to meet burden; claim rejected
Key_Evidence_Considered: Economic conditions cited as reason for non-use; lack of evidence on timing of resumption or specific impediments
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative and appellate review procedures
Defendant_Response: Economic downturn (recession) as reason for non-use
Evidence_Type: Oral/affidavit evidence on economic conditions, lack of documentary evidence on future plans
Outcome: Trademark 'Fascination' expunged; costs awarded to respondent

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after the expiration of authorized stay; filed PRRA application without new evidence.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant and spousal sponsorship applicant
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA application lacked new information; motion for stay of removal filed

Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious issue to be tried, no irreparable harm demonstrated, balance of convenience favors Minister

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subject to a removal order under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was issued a removal order due to non-compliance with residency obligations; appeal ongoing but does not stay removal order.

Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order documentation, citizenship application records
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of removal order, approval of citizenship application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Individual remains under a removal order until appeals are exhausted and order is quashed; eligibility not restored during appeal.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet minimum physical presence requirements; departure order issued and under appeal.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident (pending final determination on removal)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ongoing appeal does not negate existence of removal order for citizenship purposes
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Residency tracking records, immigration status history, appeal filings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ineligible for citizenship due to being under a removal order
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Recognition of permanent resident status, cancellation of removal order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) and (f) of Citizenship Act and IRPA s. 46(1)(c)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Despite retention of permanent resident status pending appeal, applicant is under a removal order and thus ineligible for citizenship.

Application_Facts: Mrs. Khan's citizenship claim relied on Article 45 of Guyana's Constitution, which grants discretion to authorities; the tribunal speculated on how Guyana might exercise its discretion. Mr. Khan faced credible events in Guyana but did not claim refugee status in the U.S.
Claimant_Status: Mrs. Khan used a false passport raising questions about her citizenship rights; Mr. Khan faced criminal acts in Guyana.
Misrepresentation_Element: Use of a false passport by Mrs. Khan
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to conduct a proper section 97 analysis for Mr. Khan
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Speculation by tribunal on discretionary powers under Article 45 without concrete evidence of citizenship grant
Credibility_Assessment: Questions raised about Mrs. Khanâ€™s citizenship due to use of false passport
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted for reconsideration
Relief_Sought: Recognition of right to protection under section 97
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution; requirements under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred in assuming Mrs. Khanâ€™s citizenship rights based on speculative application of discretionary constitutional provision; failed to analyze Mr. Khanâ€™s section 97 claim despite credible harm

Dispute_Type: Citizenship rights and eligibility for protection under Canadian immigration law
Legal_Issue: Whether Mrs. Khan had a right to Guyanese citizenship and whether Mr. Khan qualified for protection under section 97
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, tribunal decision quashed, case remitted
Credibility_Assessment: Mrs. Khan used false identity information on marriage certificate affecting credibility of claims
Evidence_Type: Marriage certificate with false identity information
Legal_Provision: Section 97 of IRPA; Article 45 of Guyana's Constitution
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged errors in legal interpretation and evidence assessment by tribunal
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false identity in official document (marriage certificate) leading to misrepresentation
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Application_Error: Assumption of Mrs. Khanâ€™s citizenship rights despite discretionary nature of Guyanese citizenship process
Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; proper analysis under section 97 required
Evidence_Ignored: Failure to properly assess events in Guyana relevant to Mr. Khanâ€™s risk under section 97
Legal_Standard: Standard for establishing well-founded fear and eligibility for state protection under IRPA
Application_Factor: Prior use of fraudulent documents and failure to seek protection in U.S.
Document_Fraud: False identity information on marriage certificate

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to alleged persecution in Kenya
Misrepresentation_Element: Negative credibility findings based on implausible testimony and inconsistencies
Evidence_Used: Board considered evidence submitted within procedural timelines
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to submit relevant evidence on time
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues based on plausible inferences and inconsistencies in testimony
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Appeal Division decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of negative credibility finding and referral back for re-determination
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; Board applied correct legal standard and made reasonable credibility assessment
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution due to witnessing a murder and aiding police in Malaysia; submitted a letter from Malaysian police confirming cooperation in a 1985 murder case.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to submit new evidence in a timely manner; PRRA officer assessed whether evidence was new or could have been reasonably presented earlier.
Evidence_Used: Letter from Malaysian police confirming applicant's cooperation in a 1985 murder investigation.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: The letter did not contain information that arose after the RPD hearing; no explanation provided for why it was not submitted earlier.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD previously rejected the application due to credibility issues.
Decision_Outcome: PRRA officer disregarded the letter as not constituting new evidence.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no reviewable error found.
Legal_Standard_Applied: PRRA officers must assess only new evidence that arose after rejection or was not reasonably available at the time of the original hearing.
Decision_Rationale: The evidence submitted did not post-date the RPD hearing and the applicant failed to justify the late submission; thus, the officerâ€™s decision to exclude it was reasonable.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1E of the Convention on the Status of Refugees
Governing_Law: Convention on the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Kanesharan, a Sri Lankan Tamil, fled to the UK and later Canada; Board considered a statutory declaration regarding his rights in the UK
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable â€“ claimant no longer resident in the UK
Misrepresentation_Element: Statutory declaration used tentative language about deportation and eligibility
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess whether rights were equivalent to nationality
Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of Article 1E in Canadian refugee determination process
Evidence_Used: Statutory declaration suggesting rights akin to UK nationals
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Use of speculative and non-conclusive language in the statutory declaration
Decision_Outcome: Board excluded Kanesharan from refugee status under Article 1E
Outcome: Federal Court found error, set aside decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Boardâ€™s decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee status by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of Article 1E â€“ rights and obligations substantially similar to nationality
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in relying on insufficient evidence to conclude that Kanesharan had rights akin to nationality in the UK
